sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Hey everyone, I’m Jihad Al Sayed. In this video, we’re looking at coordinate systems — how we represent vectors using a chosen basis. This is a must-know concept for everything from graphics to machine learning.

sections.title: What is a Coordinate System?
sections.content: A coordinate system expresses vectors as linear combinations of basis vectors. It gives meaning to positions and directions in space — whether you're in ℝ², ℝ³, or some abstract vector space.

sections.title: Vector Representation in a Basis
sections.math:
If B = \{v₁, v₂\} is a basis for \mathbb{R}^2, then any vector x can be written as x = a₁v₁ + a₂v₂.
\Rightarrow Coordinates of x relative to B are [a₁, a₂].

sections.title: Change of Basis
sections.content: Switching between coordinate systems requires a change of basis. This is essential in computer graphics, physics simulations, and PCA.

sections.title: Change of Basis Matrix
sections.math:
Let P be a matrix whose columns are the new basis vectors. Then:
[x]_new = P⁻¹ * x

sections.title: Graph: Basis Vectors and Vector Projection
Real-World Usage
sections.content: This is used in color transformations, sound encoding, robotics, and AI. Coordinate systems let us shift perspective, compress data, and solve systems efficiently.

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: We explored what coordinate systems are, how they work with bases, how to convert between them, and why this concept powers nearly every applied system in engineering and computer science.
